question: What mechanisms explain why low-dose lithium is neuroprotective while therapeutic-dose lithium causes nephrotoxicity, and what molecular targets determine the dose-dependent switch between cytoprotection and organ toxicity?

hypotheses.prediction: IF renal collecting duct cells express functional ENaC, THEN intracellular [Li⁺] will be 2.5–4.0× extracellular [Li⁺] at steady state (24h), while ENaC-knockout/amiloride-blocked cells will show ratios <1.5×.

IF renal cells are exposed to [Li⁺] >2 mM (mimicking renal intracellular levels), THEN AQP2 apical membrane insertion will decrease >50% within 48h, AND co-treatment with myo-inositol (10 mM) will rescue AQP2 trafficking to >75% of baseline.

IF primary cortical neurons are exposed to 0.3 mM Li⁺, THEN GSK-3β activity decreases 15–25%, Nrf2 nuclear translocation increases >2-fold, and survival after glutamate excitotoxicity improves >30%. GSK-3β-S9A mutant neurons will show NO neuroprotection, and Nrf2⁻/⁻ neurons will show >50% attenuation of protection.

IF collecting duct cells experience >50% GSK-3β inhibition (via 3 mM Li⁺), THEN β-catenin-dependent transcription (TOPFlash) increases >5-fold, with upregulation of fibrotic markers (α-SMA, collagen I, CTGF) >3-fold within 72h. At 0.3 mM Li⁺ (~20% inhibition), the same cells show <2-fold TOPFlash and no fibrotic marker induction. β-catenin knockdown will abolish fibrotic response at high [Li⁺].

protocols.prediction: IF renal collecting duct cells express functional ENaC, THEN intracellular [Li⁺] will be 2.5–4.0× extracellular [Li⁺] at steady state (24h), while ENaC-knockout/amiloride-blocked cells will show ratios <1.5×.
protocols.protocol: Culture mpkCCD (mouse principal cells) and ENaC-
protocols.expected_outcome: mpkCCD cells show [Li⁺]ᵢ/[Li⁺]ₑ = 2.5–4.0; amiloride-treated and ENaC-null cells show ratio ~1.0–1.3.
protocols.null_outcome: All conditions show ratios <2.0, or ENaC blockade does not reduce accumulation >30%.

protocols.prediction: IF renal cells are exposed to [Li⁺] >2 mM (mimicking renal intracellular levels), THEN AQP2 apical membrane insertion will decrease >50% within 48h, AND co-treatment with myo-inositol (10 mM) will rescue AQP2 trafficking to >75% of baseline.
protocols.protocol: Use mpkCCD cells stably expressing AQP2-GFP, stimulated with dDAVP (10 nM). Treat with LiCl (0.5, 1.0, 2.0, 4.0 mM) ± myo-inositol (1, 10 mM) for 48h. Quantify apical AQP2 by surface biotinylation and TIRF microscopy. Measure PI(4,5)P₂ by ELISA and IMPase activity in lysates. Include L-690,330 (IMPase inhibitor, 100 μM) as positive control. Timeline: 6 weeks.
readouts: IMPase enzymatic assay (malachite green phosphate release)
protocols.expected_outcome: Dose-dependent AQP2 surface loss (IC₅₀ ~1.5–2.5 mM Li⁺), correlated with PI(4,5)P₂ depletion; myo-inositol rescues both >70%.
protocols.null_outcome: AQP2 trafficking unaffected at 4 mM Li⁺, or inositol supplementation fails to rescue (<20% improvement), suggesting IMPase-independent mechanism.

protocols.prediction: IF primary cortical neurons are exposed to 0.3 mM Li⁺, THEN GSK-3β activity decreases 15–25%, Nrf2 nuclear translocation increases >2-fold, and survival after glutamate excitotoxicity improves >30%. GSK-3β-S9A mutant neurons will show NO neuroprotection, and Nrf2⁻/⁻ neurons will show >50% attenuation of protection.
protocols.protocol: Prepare primary cortical neurons from WT, GSK-3β-S9A knock-in, and Nrf2⁻/⁻ mice (E16). Treat with LiCl (0, 0.1, 0.3, 0.6, 1.0 mM) for 7 DIV, then challenge with glutamate (100 μM, 1h). Measure: viability (calcein/PI, 24h post-challenge), GSK-3β activity (pS9 Western + kinase assay), Nrf2 nuclear fraction (subcellular fractionation/IF), β-catenin (Western), BDNF (ELISA), HO-1/NQO1 (qPCR). Include CHIR99021 (GSK-3β inhibitor, titrated to 15–25% inhibition) as pharmacological comparator. Timeline: 8 weeks.
protocols.null_outcome: S9A neurons still protected by Li⁺ (implicating GSK-3β-independent mechanism); or Nrf2⁻/⁻ neurons fully protected (Nrf2 dispensable); or CHIR99021 at equivalent GSK-3β inhibition fails to protect (Li⁺ target is not GSK-3β).

protocols.prediction: IF collecting duct cells experience >50% GSK-3β inhibition (via 3 mM Li⁺), THEN β-catenin-dependent transcription (TOPFlash) increases >5-fold, with upregulation of fibrotic markers (α-SMA, collagen I, CTGF) >3-fold within 72h. At 0.3 mM Li⁺ (~20% inhibition), the same cells show <2-fold TOPFlash and no fibrotic marker induction. β-catenin knockdown will abolish fibrotic response at high [Li⁺].
protocols.protocol: Use mpkCCD or mIMCD-3 cells transduced with TOPFlash-luciferase reporter. Treat with LiCl (0.3, 1.0, 2.0, 3.0, 4.0 mM) for 24–96h. Measure TOPFlash activity, α-SMA/collagen I/CTGF by qPCR and Western, proliferation (Ki

final_claims.statement: 1:** The dose-dependent switch is fundamentally a pharmacokinetic phenomenon: renal collecting duct cells concentrate Li⁺ 3–4× above serum via ENaC, while brain parenchyma achieves only ~0.4–0.6× serum due to active BBB efflux (likely via sodium-dependent transporters).
final_claims.mechanism: At therapeutic serum 0.8–1.2 mM, renal medullary cells reach 2.4–4.8 mM (engaging full IMPase and substantial GSK-3β inhibition), while brain reaches 0.3–0.7 mM (partial GSK-3β inhibition only).
final_claims.falsifiable_by: Direct microdialysis or imaging mass spectrometry showing brain:serum ratios >0.8 or renal:serum ratios <2 at steady state in therapeutic dosing.

final_claims.statement: 2:** Neuroprotection at low brain [Li⁺] (0.2–0.6 mM) is driven by ~10–25% GSK-3β inhibition (Ki ~2 mM, Hill n≈1), sufficient to de-repress Nrf2/ARE antioxidant genes and stabilize β-catenin for BDNF/Wnt survival signaling, without meaningful IMPase inhibition (<15% at Ki ~0.8 mM given uncompetitive kinetics with substrate).
final_claims.mechanism: Partial GSK-3β inhibition shifts the phosphorylation balance of Nrf2 and β-catenin below the degradation threshold, activating pro-survival transcription without disrupting inositol cycling.
final_claims.falsifiable_by: GSK-3β-S9A knock-in mice (constitutively active, unresponsive to Li⁺ inhibition) showing no neuroprotection from low-dose lithium; or Nrf2-knockout abolishing the protective effect.

final_claims.statement: 3:** Nephrotoxicity requires dual-target engagement: IMPase inhibition (>70% at renal [Li⁺] >2 mM) depletes free inositol, disrupting PI(4,5)P₂-dependent AQP2 vesicle trafficking → nephrogenic diabetes insipidus as the initiating lesion; concurrent GSK-3β inhibition (>50%) dysregulates Wnt/β-catenin → aberrant proliferation and epithelial-mesenchymal transition → interstitial fibrosis over chronic exposure.
final_claims.mechanism: Synergistic disruption of two independent pathways (inositol-dependent trafficking and GSK-3β-dependent cell fate) creates a toxicity threshold that neither target alone would produce at these concentrations.
final_claims.falsifiable_by: Myo-inositol supplementation preventing NDI but not fibrosis (would dissect the two arms); or renal-specific GSK-3β constitutive activation preventing fibrosis without affecting AQP2.

final_claims.statement: 4:** Magnesium competition contributes to the dose-dependent switch — Li⁺ displaces Mg²⁺ from the catalytic metal sites of IMPase and GSK-3β with an effective Kd for displacement of ~0.5–1.0 mM, meaning low-dose tissue [Li⁺] (<0.5 mM) is insufficient for significant Mg²⁺ displacement while renal concentrations (>2 mM) achieve near-complete displacement.
final_claims.mechanism: Li⁺ (ionic radius 0.76 Å) substitutes for Mg²⁺ (0.72 Å) in the binuclear metal center of IMPase, but the substituted enzyme is catalytically incompet

final_claims.statement: 1:** The dose-dependent switch between neuroprotection and nephrotoxicity is driven by **tissue-specific lithium accumulation**, where renal medullary cells concentrate lithium 3–4× above serum via ENaC, reaching locally toxic levels (>2 mM) that fully inhibit IMPase and GSK-3β, while brain lithium remains sub-toxic (~0.4–0.6 mM) due to BBB efflux.
final_claims.mechanism: Renal ENaC-mediated lithium reabsorption creates a local "toxic microenvironment" saturating IMPase (Ki ~0.8 mM) and GSK-3β (Ki ~1.5 mM), while the brain’s lower [Li⁺] only partially inhibits GSK-3β (~20–30%), activating neuroprotective Wnt/β-catenin signaling.
final_claims.falsifiable_by: - In vivo microdialysis showing renal medulla [Li⁺] <2 mM at therapeutic serum doses. - ENaC knockout mice exhibiting reduced nephrotoxicity without altered brain [Li⁺]. ---

final_claims.statement: 2:** **IMPase inhibition is the primary driver of nephrotoxicity**, with inositol depletion disrupting AQP2 trafficking and PI signaling, initiating nephrogenic diabetes insipidus (NDI) and chronic tubular stress.
final_claims.mechanism: At renal [Li⁺] >2 mM, IMPase (Ki ~0.8 mM) is >70% inhibited, depleting inositol pools required for PI(4,5)P₂ synthesis, impairing AQP2 vesicle fusion and causing osmotic stress.
final_claims.falsifiable_by: - Inositol supplementation rescuing AQP2 trafficking in lithium-treated renal cells. - IMPase-overexpressing mice showing reduced NDI at therapeutic [Li⁺]. ---

final_claims.statement: 3:** **GSK-3β inhibition exhibits a biphasic effect**: 10–30% inhibition (brain [Li⁺] ~0.4 mM) activates Nrf2/ARE and Wnt/β-catenin for neuroprotection, while >50% inhibition (renal [Li⁺] >2 mM) dysregulates glycogen metabolism and β-catenin-driven proliferation, contributing to renal fibrosis.
final_claims.mechanism: Partial GSK-3β inhibition stabilizes β-catenin and Nrf2, while full inhibition disrupts β-catenin degradation, leading to maladaptive proliferation and fibrosis.
final_claims.falsifiable_by: - GSK-3β activity assays in brain vs. kidney at varying [Li⁺], correlated with β-catenin/Nrf2 targets. - β-catenin or Nrf2 knockout mice losing neuroprotection or gaining nephrotoxicity, respectively. ---

final_claims.statement: 4:** **Magnesium competition modulates the dose-dependent switch**, with therapeutic [Li⁺] (0.6–1.2 mM) displacing Mg²⁺ from IMPase/GSK-3β active sites, while low-dose lithium (<0.5 mM) does not.
final_claims.mechanism: Lithium’s ionic radius mimics Mg²⁺, competitively inhibiting Mg²⁺-dependent enzymes (IMPase, GSK-3β) only when [Li⁺] approaches the Kd for Mg²⁺ displacement (~0.5–1 mM).
final_claims.falsifiable_by: - In vitro assays showing Mg²⁺ supplementation rescuing IMPase/GSK-3β activity at [Li⁺] = 1 mM. - In vivo Mg²⁺ co-administration

final_claims.statement: Nephrotoxicity arises from ENaC-mediated Li⁺ accumulation in renal principal cells to 2-4 mM at therapeutic serum (0.8-1.2 mM), saturating IMPase (>80% inhibition, Ki~0.8 mM) and GSK-3β (>50%, Ki~1.5 mM).
final_claims.mechanism: IMPase inhibition depletes inositol, blocking PI3K/Akt signaling for AQP2 vesicle trafficking to apical membrane, causing NDI; GSK-3β adds mitochondrial stress.
final_claims.falsifiable_by: ENaC knockout mice showing no renal Li accumulation or toxicity at therapeutic serum.

final_claims.statement: Neuroprotection at low-dose serum Li (0.1-0.6 mM; brain [Li⁺]~0.05-0.3 mM) via partial GSK-3β inhibition (10-30%, Ki~1.5 mM), sparing IMPase (<20%).
final_claims.mechanism: Partial GSK-3β inhibition stabilizes β-catenin (Wnt) and activates Nrf2/ARE for antioxidant/BDNF responses without inositol depletion.
final_claims.falsifiable_by: GSK-3β S9A knockin neurons lacking neuroprotection at low [Li⁺].

final_claims.statement: Dose-switch is a tissue-[Li⁺] phenomenon: kidney [Li⁺] hits TD50~2 mM (therapeutic_index~10 vs brain ED50~0.2 mM) due to ENaC/NKA, while brain stays sub-toxic.
final_claims.mechanism: Hill n=1 yields brain 15-25% GSK-3β inhibition (protective) vs renal >70% dual-target saturation (toxic).
final_claims.falsifiable_by: ICP-MS quantifying intracellular [Li⁺] in human iPSC-kidney/brain organoids at matched serum.

final_claims.statement: Mg²⁺ competition contributes to dose-dependence: therapeutic [Li⁺] displaces Mg²⁺ (Kd~0.5 mM) from IMPase/GSK-3β, amplifying inhibition.
final_claims.mechanism: Li⁺ (ionic radius 76 pm vs Mg 72 pm) competes only when [Li⁺] nears Mg site occupancy, shifting low-dose partial to high-dose full block.
final_claims.falsifiable_by: Mg supplementation failing to rescue IMPase activity in renal cells at 2 mM Li⁺.

final_claims.statement: High renal [Li⁺] inhibits mito Complex I (ND2/4 binding), exacerbating toxicity beyond IMPase/GSK-3β.
final_claims.mechanism: Direct subunit binding at >2 mM generates ROS, synergizing with inositol depletion for apoptosis/fibrosis.
final_claims.falsifiable_by: Complex I assays showing no Li⁺ IC50 <5 mM. ───

final_claims.statement: The dose-dependent switch is a direct consequence of pharmacokinetic partitioning creating two distinct biological regimes. Renal collecting ducts concentrate Li⁺ via ENaC to 2-4 mM, while the brain maintains Li⁺ at 0.4-0.6 mM. This differential dosing is the primary determinant of tissue-specific outcomes.
final_claims.mechanism: ENaC in renal principal cells actively transports Li⁺, causing accumulation, whereas BBB efflux pumps maintain low brain concentrations, creating a steep concentration gradient between the two tissues.
final_claims.falsifiable_by: Evidence of a cell-autonomous switch in cultured neurons and renal cells exposed to the *same* lithium concentration.

final_claims.statement: The molecular switch is governed by the relative Ki values of IMPase (Ki ≈ 0.8 mM) and GSK-3β (Ki ≈ 2.0 mM). Neuroprotection occurs at brain [Li⁺]i (~0.5 mM) causing partial (~20%) GSK-3β inhibition with minimal IMPase effects, while nephrotoxicity occurs at kidney [Li⁺]i (>2.0 mM) causing >75% IMPase saturation *and* >50% GSK-3β inhibition, a synergistically toxic state.
final_claims.mechanism: The neuroprotective window exists where [Li⁺]i is sufficient to modulate GSK-3β but below the Ki of IMPase; the toxic threshold is crossed when [Li⁺]i significantly surpasses the Ki of IMPase, causing catastrophic inositol depletion.
final_claims.falsifiable_by: In vivo evidence that selective GSK-3β inhibition is nephrotoxic, or that IMPase inhibition alone is not.

final_claims.statement: The biophysical basis for lithium's action is competitive displacement of the cofactor Mg²⁺. Li⁺ inhibits Mg²⁺-dependent enzymes (IMPase, GSK-3β) only when its local concentration becomes high enough (~0.5-1.0 mM) to effectively compete with intracellular free Mg²⁺ at the catalytic site.
final_claims.mechanism: The similar ionic radius of Li⁺ and Mg²⁺ allows Li⁺ to act as an antagonist at Mg²⁺ binding sites, an effect that follows mass action principles and is thus concentration-dependent.
final_claims.falsifiable_by: In vitro enzyme assays demonstrating that increasing [Mg²⁺] competitively reverses lithium-induced inhibition of IMPase and GSK-3β. ───

final_claims.statement: 1: The neuroprotective-toxic switch is primarily determined by the local concentration exceeding the IMPase Ki (~0.8 mM), which occurs in renal medulla but not brain at therapeutic serum levels.
final_claims.mechanism: ENaC-mediated Li⁺ uptake in renal principal cells raises intracellular [Li⁺] to >2 mM, fully inhibiting IMPase and causing inositol depletion, disrupting PI signaling and AQP2 trafficking, initiating nephrogenic DI and chronic stress.
final_claims.falsifiable_by: Measuring direct renal tubular [Li⁺] in vivo and finding it does not exceed 1 mM at serum levels of 1.2 mM, or showing that IMPase knockout does not mimic lithium's renal effects.

final_claims.statement: 2: Low-dose neuroprotection (0.2-0.5 mM serum) arises from ~10-25% inhibition of GSK-3β in neurons, activating β-catenin and Nrf2/ARE pathways, while sparing IMPase (<5% inhibition).
final_claims.mechanism: Partial GSK-3β inhibition shifts the balance of pro-survival vs. pro-apoptotic signaling, enhancing mitochondrial biogenesis and antioxidant defense without triggering inositol-depletion stress.
final_claims.falsifiable_by: Demonstrating that GSK-3β inhibition to the same degree (e.g., with specific inhibitors) at low [Li⁺] does not produce neuroprotection, or that Li⁺ neuroprotection persists in GSK-3β knockout neurons.

final_claims.statement: 3: Magnesium competition is a plausible amplifier of the dose-dependent switch: at renal tubular [Li⁺] >1 mM, Li⁺ displaces Mg²⁺ from IMPase/GSK-3β active sites, exacerbating inhibition, while at brain [Li⁺] <0.5 mM, Mg²⁺ buffering prevents significant displacement.
final_claims.mechanism: Li⁺ (ionic radius ~0.76 Å) mimics Mg²⁺ (~0.72 Å) but binds with lower affinity; high local [Li⁺] outcompetes physiological [Mg²⁺] (~0.5-1 mM) at enzyme active sites, leading to non-physiological, sustained inhibition.
final_claims.falsifiable_by: In vitro kinetics showing Mg²⁺ supplementation does not alter Li⁺ inhibition constants for IMPase/GSK-3β, or in vivo Mg²⁺ supplementation failing to alter the therapeutic window for nephrotoxicity.
